Award.AwardTitle: Indigenous Calendar Knowledge, Research Protocols, and Visualization Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines the social, technical, and cultural processes of integrating Indigenous scientific knowledge with digital media platforms. The Otomi people of the central Mexican plateau have developed extensive astronomical knowledge systems for calendrical timekeeping over thousands of years based on observations of lunar, solar, and Venusian cycles. Efforts are underway to collaborate with the Otomi people to digitize and preserve their indigenous astronomical knowledge. This will enable Otomi knowledge-holders to share their cosmological knowledge locally, regionally, and globally. However, digital technologies like virtual reality environments and three-dimensional imaging can also warp conceptions of space and time, creating distortions much like a two-dimensional map distorts landmasses, challenging translational processes. This project documents the intersection of knowledge systems as community knowledge held through narratives, images, and intergenerational exchange is translated into digital systems marked by computational standardization and 3-d cameras. Researchers will analyze participatory design processes as Indigenous ethno-scientists, digital media-makers, and traditional knowledge-holders collaborate to create a prototype virtual reality representation. The project will encourage Hispanic and Native American studentsâ€™ interest in STEM careers and STS research, which is vital to the American workforce, while also assessing the ways that virtual reality technologies may contribute to Indigenous knowledge reclamations and cultural sustainability.

Drawing upon data collected through round table discussions and participatory design sessions, and informed by Actor-Network Theory, this research addresses four main questions: (1) Who are the primary collaborators involved in translating Indigenous astronomical knowledge and what materials will they use to create a novel form of Indigenous technoscience? (2) Can immersive 3-D audio-visual technology accurately convey the complex tenets of Indigenous epistemology? (3) What kinds of knowledge, interface design, or data standardization will be needed to effectively accomplish a best-case model for other Indigenous communities around the world? (4) What kind of protocols and methodologies can enable a best-case practice for ensuring that Indigenous communities and their knowledge are respected and not exploited? Overall, this research investigates the processes needed to standardize Indigenous calendar visualizations for public and community presentation, with the guidance of Indigenous knowledge keepers and according to the protocols of participating with Indigenous communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title: Indigenous Knowledge Visualization: Otomi Calendar in a Dome Planetarium

Principal Investigator: Mark Palmer

Project Duration: 08/01/2022 to 07/31/2023

Project Overview:

The project aimed to explore the intersection of Indigenous knowledge systems, particularly focusing on the Otomi calendar, and modern visualization technologies. It sought to translate Indigenous cosmological knowledge into a dome planetarium presentation prototype through collaboration between Indigenous knowledge holders, filmmakers, animators, video technicians, and academics.

Key Findings and Outcomes:

 Indigenous Data and Research Sovereignty: The project exemplified Indigenous data and research sovereignty by centering Indigenous knowledge holders in the creation process. Through collaboration and respectful engagement, the project empowered Otomi people to reclaim, preserve, and share their cultural heritage in a digital format.

International Collaboration: The project fostered international collaboration among participants from Mexico, United States, Peru, and Canada. This diverse team brought together expertise in Indigenous timekeeping, filmmaking, animation, and academia, enriching the project with varied perspectives and skills.

Documentation and Preservation: The research team collected and recorded extensive interviews with Otomi elders, ensuring the documentation and preservation of oral traditions related to the Otomi calendar. These recordings serve as valuable resources for future research and cultural preservation efforts.

Cultural Representation: Filmmaker and Hopi knowledge holder, Victor Masayesva, led the creation of a culturally appropriate visualization script and storyboard. The dome planetarium presentation accurately represented Otomi calendar knowledge and was designed to educate and inspire audiences, particularly youth, about Indigenous cosmology.

Knowledge Transmission: The project facilitated the transmission of Otomi cosmological knowledge and traditional timekeeping practices to wider audiences. The dome planetarium presentation, available in Otomi and Spanish languages, serves as an educational tool for schools, museums, and communities interested in learning about Indigenous cultures.

Impact and Future Directions:

The project's impact extends beyond the academic realm, contributing to cultural revitalization, intergenerational knowledge transfer, and Indigenous empowerment. Moving forward, the project lays the groundwork for similar initiatives that seek to integrate Indigenous knowledge systems with modern technologies, promoting cultural sustainability and respect for diverse ways of knowing.

Acknowledgments:

We gratefully acknowledge the contributions of Indigenous knowledge holders, filmmakers, animators, video technicians, and academics who participated in this project. Their dedication, expertise, and commitment to cultural preservation made this endeavor possible.

Funding Source:

This project was supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number NSF2020707.
